body: Definitely seems a tensor flow issue. I am trying to work through [these instructions](https://github.com/apple/tensorflow_macos/issues/153) to install apple's version of TF 2.5 for arm.

I've spent a few hours on this, and made some progress but can't quite get everything to work. For other's interested, here's what I've figure out.

Prior to dlc 2.2rc3, deeplabcut could install and run in anaconda using rosetta2.
deeplabcut 2.2rc3 requires tensorflow 2.5, but there isn't a rosetta2 emulator version available.

So, you can install miniforge to replace conda, which will then grab non emulated ARM versions of packages (it still uses conda commands) and the apple alpha release of tf 2.5 following [these instructions](https://developer.apple.com/metal/tensorflow-plugin/). But that version of tf won't be recognized by pip when installing deeplabcut and creates a dependency problem.

So I installed what I could of the dlc dependencies via miniforge conda, and the rest via pip.  This let me import deeplabcut in pythonw, but it only imported in light mode. 

I tried to run the test script, but got the very interesting error below. I've never seen a **Mangled stack trace** before.

<details><summary>installation lines I ran</summary>

```python
conda create -n appletf25python39 python=3.9
conda activate appletf25python39
conda install -c apple tensorflow-deps
python -m pip install tensorflow-macos
python -m pip install tensorflow-metal
conda install python.app filterpy ruamel.yaml imgaug numba scikit-image scikit-learn statsmodels tqdm moviepy jupyter nb_conda ffmpeg
python -m pip install tensorpack tf_slim tables
python -m pip install 'deeplabcut[gui]'==2.2rc3 --no-deps
python -m pip install opencv-python-headless # This fails, but opencv is already installed
```

</details>

<details><summary>testscript.py results</summary>

```python
pythonw testscript.py

  warnings.warn('resource_tracker: There appear to be %d '
```

</details>

**Conclusions:**

Some of the dependencies just aren't updated to work on ARM natively (see `opencv-python-headless`), and/or this version of tensor flow isn't quite ready for deeplabcut, or I'm missing something obvious which could be very likely. 

For now, M1 Macs might be limited to dlc 2.2rc2 (or 2.1.10.4)
Hey Brandon, super sorry - we will also look into this! to note, we did test rc3 with TF2.0 - 2.5, so if an older version works, that works for DLC!

Some of the opencv libraries have been updated for ARM, so I've made some progress.  Based on the following, I've gotten DLC training and video analysis to engage the M1 GPU.  However, there are a few problems:
1. DLC only imports in `lite` mode (no GUIs)
2. any function that engages the GPU triggers a segmentation fault when it finishes:

<details>

```
deeplabcut.evaluate_network(config)
Running  DLC_resnet50_TESTJul12shuffle1_5  with # of trainingiterations: 5
/Users/brandonjackson/opt/miniforge3/envs/tftest/lib/python3.9/site-packages/tensorflow/python/keras/engine/base_layer_v1.py:1692: UserWarning: `layer.apply` is deprecated and will be removed in a future version. Please use `layer.__call__` method instead.
  warnings.warn('`layer.apply` is deprecated and '
Metal device set to: Apple M1
Analyzing data...
5it [00:01,  4.31it/s]
*** Received signal 11 ***
*** BEGIN MANGLED STACK TRACE ***
/Users/brandonjackson/opt/miniforge3/envs/tftest/bin/pythonw: line 3: 49309 Segmentation fault: 11  /Users/brandonjackson/opt/miniforge3/envs/tftest/python.app/Contents/MacOS/python "$@"
(tftest) brandonjackson@Staceys-MacBook-Pro examples % /Users/brandonjackson/opt/miniforge3/envs/tftest/lib/python3.9/multiprocessing/resource_tracker.py:216: UserWarning: resource_tracker: There appear to be 1 leaked semaphore objects to clean up at shutdown
  warnings.warn('resource_tracker: There appear to be %d '
```

</details>

Here's how I got this far:

1. Install homebrew, and once that's installed run `brew install ffmpeg`. For some reason, the ARM capable opencv packages only look for certain libraries in `opt/homebrew/...` I tried creating those directories and shortcuts to conda ffmpeg, but that didn't work. 
2. Install miniforge as described [here](https://github.com/apple/tensorflow_macos/issues/153). It was a little tricky to get the zsh path to see it rather than Miniconda, but there's lots of help online. Basically you have to make sure miniforge installs in the user's opt folder, then manually edit the .zshrc paths from miniconda to miniforge.
3. Once the "sanity checks" pass, don't follow the rest of those directions to install TensorFlow in an env because it clashes with DLC dependencies, rather:

```
conda create -n tftest python=3.9
conda activate tftest
conda install -c apple tensorflow-deps
python -m pip install tensorflow-macos
python -m pip install tensorflow-metal
conda install python.app filterpy ruamel.yaml imgaug numba scikit-image scikit-learn statsmodels tqdm moviepy jupyter nb_conda
python -m pip install tensorpack tf_slim tables
python -m pip install 'deeplabcut[gui]'==2.2rc3 --no-deps
python -m pip install opencv-python-headless
```

4. At that point, deeplabcut imports in pythonw.
5. Everything up until training works. Training produces snapshots (and uses the GPU), but the segmentation error crashes python when the GPU is being released. 
6. Evaluate network give the same error and does not produce any output 
7. Analyze videos works and uses the GPU, produces the h5 and pickle files, but the crashes with the seg fault.

## so what?

If you're desperate to run training and analysis on your M1, this can get you started, but you have to work around the crashes, and will need functioning GUI installation of an older DLC to run in a separate env.  Colab is still probably easier.

So will 2.2rc3 work without GPU on M1?
I just need access to the label frames GUI. I have access to a server with GPU to do actual training.
I'm also considering writing an imageJ/FIJI plugin or a Javascript GUI to embed in Jupyter notebook to label images

@outlace it's a release candidate so we can work through these things - for the full release we will find a solution; now you can easily install 2.10.4 on an M1, which is the stable release. You are welcome of course to write your own GUI but do be warned for multi-animal things it's not the most trivial endeavor.
actually I see you all made a Dash app for labeling donated data, the DeepLabCut WebApp. Is there any reason that can't be made to handle personal data and embedded in a Jupyter/Colab notebook?

I got 2.2rc3 to install on M1 Macs (without GPU support, unfortunately)

2.2rc3 requires TensorFlow 2.5 which does not work on M1
even through Rosetta, you get an invalid instruction error.
However, according to here: https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/46044
if you compile TensorFlow from source through Rosetta it works.

You can get a pre-compiled wheel of TensorFlow 2.5 that will
work through Rosetta. All the following is done in a Rosetta Terminal.
1. Make sure you have miniconda or anaconda installed
2. `git clone https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut.git`
3. `cd DeepLabCut/conda-environments`
4. Edit DEEPLABCUT.yaml and change python version from 3.8 to 3.7
5. `conda env create -f DEEPLABCUT.yaml`
6. `conda activate deeplabcut`
7. Download the Rosetta pre-compiled TensorFlow 2.5 wheel from here:
https://drive.google.com/file/d/17pSwfoNuyf3YR8vCaVggHeI-pMQ3xL7l/view?usp=sharing
8. `pip install tensorflow-2.4.1-py3-none-any.whl`
 (if that doesn't work, you may first need to do `pip install wheel`)
 Now you should have TensorFlow 2.4 installed
9. `conda install python.app`
10. Run `pythonw -m deeplabcut`
The GUI should appear
@outlace thanks! note any TF2 is possible; we unpinned it in the setup so 2.2 will be any TF2, and of course 3.7 is possible as well.

@outlace note that python 3.8 is supported for TF2.5 on M1, but the step 4 is required due to the wheel you give in that link - @outlace could you point me to where you found the link to download the rosetta TF; seems to be a 2.4.1 file

Note the alternative option from [this blog](https://caffeinedev.medium.com/how-to-install-tensorflow-on-m1-mac-8e9b91d93706) is: 

- after activating DEEPLABCUT with `conda activate DEEPLABCUT`,
- run: `conda install -c apple tensorflow-deps`
- then: `pip install tensorflow-macos`
- then: `pip install tensorflow-metal` 
albeit, I did not have success with this path

> actually I see you all made a Dash app for labeling donated data, the DeepLabCut WebApp. Is there any reason that can't be made to handle personal data and embedded in a Jupyter/Colab notebook?

correct; that is an active project, see our roadmap: https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md

rename.from: 2.2rc3 will not install on M1 Macs
rename.to: `line 3: 76717 Illegal instruction: 4` -->  2.2rc3 will not install on M1 Macs

issue.title: DLC 2.2 for macoS M1 chips

repository.name: DeepLabCut
repository.description: Official implementation of DeepLabCut: Markerless pose estimation of user-defined features with deep learning for all animals incl. humans

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
Based on issue #1380, and in particular comment https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/issues/1380#issuecomment-880386594, here is a DLC environment that works on M1 chips (freshly acquired - today - macbook pro was used for testing that had High Sierra installed). 

Use this (DEEPLABCUT_M1.yaml) conda file if you have an M1, and follow these steps:

### DeepLabCut M1 chip installation environment instructions (assuming you have anaconda installed!):

(1) git clone the deeplabcut cut repo:

`git clone https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut.git`

(2) in the program terminal, `cd DeepLabCut/conda-environments`

(3) Click here to download the Rosetta wheel for TensorFlow 2.4.1:
https://drive.google.com/file/d/17pSwfoNuyf3YR8vCaVggHeI-pMQ3xL7l/view?usp=sharing

(4) Then, run:

`conda env create -f DEEPLABCUT_M1.yaml`

(5) Next, **activate the environment,** and in the terminal `cd` to  Downloads, and then run:

`pip install tensorflow-2.4.1-py3-none-any.whl --no-dependencies --force-reinstall`

(6) Next, launch DLC with `pythonw -m deeplabcut`

GUI will open!

body: See #1430 for resolution (as best we can until TF and Mac plays a little nicer ;)
